fields.headline: Pick of  the day
fields.bodyText: Thirty Years and More (3.45pm, Radio 4) ought to be dull as hell: five interviews with couples of long standing, telling us what has kept them together. But the first programme is a delight, as Melanie McFadyean talks to Eddie and Chris Needham. They're the grandparents of Ben Needham, who disappeared as a toddler on the island of Kos in 1991, but this is only partly about that loss. They're keener to speak about their courtship, their frequent rows and whatever it is that has always reconciled them. You wouldn't want to marry either of them (he used to be too fond of the sauce; she once set fire to all his clothes) but they're as likable as they are entertaining. There's a corker later in the week as well, when McFadyean meets playwright Julian Mitchell and philosopher Richard Rowson - the incorrigible romantic living with the self-styled sceptic. What else? Lots of tennis, if you can take that seriously. Simon Mayo and Clare Balding present live coverage of all the prancing and grunting in Wimbledon (12.30pm, 5 Live; 12.55pm, 5 Live Sports Extra), while Des Lynam chews the post-match fat with any leftover pundits in Des at Wimbledon (7pm, 5 Live). You'll learn more from Ferry Across the Mekong (8pm, Radio 4). Former Blue Peter presenter Simon Groom is back in Cambodia, the country he first visited in 1979. That was just after the fall of Pol Pot, and what he saw changed his whole view of life; what will he make of Cambodia today?
